citation.article-title: Phylogeny by a polyphasic approach of the order Caulobacterales, proposal of Caulobacter mirabilis sp. nov., Phenylobacterium haematophilum sp. nov. and Phenylobacterium conjunctum sp. nov., and emendation of the genus Phenylobacterium.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Phenylobacterium haematophilum sp. nov.
Phenylobacterium haematophilum (hae.ma.to.phi′lum. Gr. n. haema -atos blood; Gr. adj. philos loving; N.L. neut. adj. haematophilum blood-loving).

The description of Phenylobacterium haematophilum is the same as that given for the genus (Lingens et al., 1985) and emended by Kanso & Patel (2004) and in this study, with the following additional characteristics.
The polar lipid fraction contains phosphatidylglycerols, sulfoquinovosyl diacylglycerol of 834 amu and 6-phosphatidyl-α-d-glucopyranosyl diacylglycerol of 1413 amu or higher.
Major fatty acids are C18 : 1ω7 and C16 : 0 (see Supplementary Table S1), minor fatty acids are summed feature 4, C15 : 0 and trans-11-methyl-12-octadecenoic acid.
The main hydroxyl fatty acid is C12 : 0 3-OH (see Supplementary Table S1).
Is able to grow on peptone-yeast extract media with 0–10 g l−1 NaCl with optimal growth at around 5 g l−1 NaCl.
Does not tolerate salt concentrations above 20 g l−1 NaCl.
Growth is observed between 10 and 40 °C, with optimal growth around 37 °C.

Positive in results for activities of acid and alkaline phosphatase, esterase (C4), leucine arylamidase, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase and for weak activities of cystine arylamidase, esterase lipase (C8), trypsin, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, α-glucosidase and α-chymotrypsin.
No activity is detected for α-fucosidase, α- and β-galactosidase, α-glucuronidase, β-glucosidase, α-mannosidase and valine arylamidase.

Is able to utilize arabinose, citrate, β-hydroxybutyric acid, α-d-glucose, l-glutamic acid, glycyl-l-glutamic acid, itaconic acid, maltose, mannose, methyl β-d-glucoside, methyl pyruvate, l-proline, propionate, sebacic acid and Tweens 40 and 80.

Does not utilize acetate, N-acetyl-d-glucosamine, cis-aconitic acid, adonitol, alaninamide, l- and d-alanine, l-alanylglycine, γ-aminobutyric acid, 2-aminoethanol, d-arabitol, l-asparagine, l-aspartic acid, bromosuccinic acid, 2,3-butanediol, dl-carnitine, cellobiose, α-cyclodextrin, dextrin, i-erythritol, formate, d-fructose, l-fucose, d-galactonic acid lactone, d-galactose, d-galacturonic acid, gentiobiose, d-gluconic acid, d-glucosaminic acid, glucose 1- and 6-phosphate, glucuronamide, d-glucuronic acid, glycerol, dl-α-glycerolphosphate, glycogen, glycyl-l-aspartic acid, l-histidine, α-hydroxybutyric acid, γ-hydroxybutyric acid, p-hydroxyphenylacetic acid, hydroxy l-proline, inosine, myo-inositol, α-ketobutyric acid, α-ketoglutaric acid, α-ketovaleric acid, dl-lactate, α-lactose, l-leucine, malonate, d-mannitol, melibiose, monomethylsuccinate, l-ornithine, l-phenylalanine, phenylethylamine, psicose, putrescine, l-pyroglutamic acid, quinic acid, raffinose, l-rhamnose, d-saccharic acid, d- and l-serine, d-sorbitol, succinamic acid, succinate, sucrose, l-threonine, thymidine, trehalose, turanose, uridine, urocanic acid and xylitol.

The species can use adonitol but not (+)-l-arabinose, caprate, β-(+)-d-fructose, (+)-d-galactose, α-(+)-d-glucose, glycerol, l-histidine, myo-inositol, α-lactose, maltose, d-mannitol, (+)-d-mannose, d-sorbitol, sucrose, (+)-d-trehalose or (+)-d-xylose.
The type strain, LMG 11050T (=CCUG 26751T), was isolated from human blood (Göteborg, Sweden).
